segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Good morning. Good evening, everyone. Hello, Zyfkon. Today, I'm going to take you to Africa
to talk about African financial threats. So about the threat groups that are targeting
banks to conduct cyber heists. Just to explain to you why such topic, why not another APT
topic about the cyber espionage intrusions. Mainly because last year,
I did a big change in my life. I left the military sector and I joined private sector
at the International Bank. And I was absolutely challenged with my knowledge about threat groups
that are financially motivated. And my current employer is present on many international
markets globally in Asia, Middle East, and also in Africa. So I decided to
understand more of the threats that are coming from that landscape. So today, I'm
taking you to Kenya, where most of those prolific groups come from, and we'll try to understand
their modus operandi and very unique kill chain of intrusions that's connected with
African origin threat groups. So for today's agenda, I prepared following points. At first,
we'll focus on these unique tactics from the past intrusions, the so-called African kill chain,
because this is quite unique for those groups and different from other operations globally.
Later on, we'll focus on things that differentiate those groups. We'll try to understand the threat
landscape and the clustering of those groups, what differentiate them. And also, we'll talk
about some history and some developments of those groups. And the third point are two case studies
focus on analyzing the capabilities, for example, Python keyloggers, which are very common among
those groups. And we're trying to understand the origin and the development of those keyloggers.
And lastly, we'll try to understand the capabilities and infrastructure of the
grab zone threat group. And we'll focus on one of the IPs that is associated with this group
in 2020. And we'll try to understand capabilities that were projected using that infrastructure.
Just a few words about me. I served about 16 years in Polish Armed Forces. I started
in Polish Navy and ended in National Cyber Security Center Poland. And now I'm working
as a Senior Manager for Cyber Threat Intelligence at Standard Chartered.
And probably some of you may ask who Threat Intel Analyst is. So this is generally somebody
who tries to connect the dots, who tries to understand the capabilities and tries to understand
threats, sometimes connecting the making, looking for the patterns, looking for the human
fingerprints that are left by adversaries. Often it is very similar to searching for a needle in
the haystack. Sometimes you get lost in a rabbit hole. But sometimes when you are successful, you
can try to find out the pattern. And the pattern can help you to understand those threat groups and
to proactively track them. And a disclaimer for this presentation is that those opinions are solely
my own and they do not represent my employer's position. And generally, the investigation,
especially the two case studies are based on publicly available data.
And I have to underline the samples, the clustering of threat groups and the naming
convention is thanks to Honored Services. I will refer to this group, to this company
in several places during my presentation, because those are the people and the company
that inspired me to do that research when I decided to focus on Africa. It is a group of
people who support targeted organizations and they provide very unique services.
Apart from incident response services, they are also authorized by government to conduct
offensive actions against those threat groups. And many of the samples, many of the threat data
also come from those offensive cyber-enabled operations. And I have to underline here that
they are very brave people because they are fighting those threats there locally,
often with close proximity to the threat groups that are very dangerous
and the risk is real for them. So let's begin with understanding the African threat
kill chain, because this is something very unique. And when most of the cyber intrusions that we know
globally are conducted remotely, often the intrusion vector is spear phishing. So this is
not the case for the African kill chain, because the initial foothold is gained using the
rogue devices that are attached by insiders, by bribed personnel, disgruntled people
who are instructed by the members of the cyber gangs to attach them somewhere
to the network of the targeted organization. So actually those intrusions are very targeted.
People are instructed to attach those devices into those networks.
And if you look to the MITRE ATT&CK matrix, there is such a technique in the initial access tactic.
It is called hardware additions. But if you check there, there are not many examples.
For example, there is only one threat group mentioned there, DarkViznia, which is an Eastern European
threat actor associated with intrusions in Europe against Eastern European banks.
So we can see on this example that in public domain, we don't have many examples, usually because
remote intrusions is actually the beauty of cyber operations.
It is very useful for espionage organizations because it is cheap.
The risk of catching is very low. And that's why so many actors use those remote attacks.
However, in Africa, most of the attacks are enabled by the rogue devices specially prepared.
And that's the way how actors gain access to the victims.
So we can also say that the intruders will get in. So the approach
that assumes breach is very actual there. And it means that threat hunting and proactive
searching for the threat actor that's already operating in our environment
is something that should be a priority for organizations that conduct business,
for example, financial institutions that are present in this region.
The next step when the adversary attaches the laptop is, of course, the reconnaissance.
Probably you are interested in what kind of laptop is this. So this is usually the
laptop with Windows operating system with commercially available commercial off-the-shelf
software for remote access tools. So it could be, for example, go to my PC.
It could be TeamViewer. It could be AnyDesk. So they usually deploy them very easy to install
and easy to operate applications for remote access control with graphical interface.
And usually those insiders are trained how to attach the laptop, how to troubleshoot.
Those laptops usually have disabled suspension or hibernation mode so they never sleep.
When they get access and there is a command control established with a quite simple mean,
the next step would be to go laterally. And apart from those command control software,
there is also a software to scan the network, to crack the passwords, to move laterally.
And for example, if they get some passwords to move laterally, they use old good PSXX. So
in this case, they do not differ from prolific groups, espionage groups that also use that kind
of software. And when they move laterally, what else they do? Oh, for reconnaissance,
you have also the images of Bloodhound and CME. So the projects which are open source and are
freely available for reconnaissance and for attacking active directory environments.
And if they find interesting stations, they install keyloggers. This is also something
very typical for them. I use that citation from Phineas Fisher, another thread actor,
that the reality is that Mimikatz and keyloggers view all passwords equally. And that's true.
Usually, they do not focus on dumping passwords and those kinds of techniques. They usually
deploy keyloggers. And we'll focus on some details of those keyloggers later on during
the case studies. And those keyloggers are very popular for all the groups. And they were
invented years ago. And with really slight differences in the code, they are being
continuously used in the intrusions. So finally, when the actors get the passwords to the critical
systems, then they enable access. And they, for example, so the intrusions, here we focus on the
technical part. But actually, there is not only one insider during the cyber intrusion. Usually,
there are more. And for example, other insider threats could be people who have access to the
account systems. And they create account accounts. And closely before the intrusion begins,
some the ATM cards for those accounts are being taken out of the bank, and they are being delivered
to the money mules. So during the operations, intruders are focused to gain maximum access to
the critical system so they can allow transactions to those money mule accounts without the limits.
So there is no alerts. And also, the cashouts from the ATMs could be done without the
limitations. Everything is organized. It could be like even hundreds or tens, hundreds of money
mules when the operators get the access. And the money mules operate in different regions. They go
to different cities. Sometimes, they cross borders, and they cash out the money mule accounts.
It's really good to understand the history of those groups. For example, in 2014, the big cartel
was formed. It was called Fork Bombo Cartel. It was created in Kasarani, which is kind of a
cyber criminal Silicon Valley. This is a ghetto area of Nairobi when there are many people,
many criminals from Nigeria, from South Africa. And there was a man who was a former policeman,
a DCI, who formed this Fork Bombo Cartel from the smaller groups. And they were quite prolific for
years. Then they split due to some arrests. So generally, if we would take the diamond model
for this group, it was a group that was operated in East Africa. It was created by the policemen.
And what is very important, those groups have often the support of the local governments,
of the police, of the corrupted policemen. So it's very hard for the defenders,
and for the targeted organizations to fight those threats. What kind of capabilities they used?
So they used commercial off-the-shell RADs like TeamViewer, GoToPC, Metasploit, PS Empire.
They used C-Duke, which is a Python-based RAD. They used QuazaRAD, which is available on the
GitHub. Of course, they used the Python keyloggers. And they used insiders, mostly from the ICT
personnel. And very often, they used third-party infrastructure. For example, they exfiltrated
the keylogging to Gmail. And the victims, for example, banks, but also some SACOs,
other financial institutions. And they were very prolific until the arrest, which happened in 2017.
And the big cartel was arrested, but many of the members managed to escape. So five smaller
groups were created then, like Silent Cards, GrabZone, smaller version of Forkbombo, Forkbombo Group,
The Doctors, and The Telecode. And some of the groups were fighting each other, some were cooperating.
For example, the GrabZone group was very close to the people that were connected
previously with Forkbombo cartel. Later on, some of the people from GrabZone and the old
money mills created the Forkbombo Group in 2018. On the other hand, there were Silent Cards that
were not cooperating that much with other groups that split with them. Later on, even Silent Cards
split to the consultants and to Rue Rue Shepherds. And for example, the person who created
Silent Cards, Forkbombo cartel, and the consultants is still the same person.
So he managed to escape and created next groups consequently.
And finally, the Forkbombo Group was terminated at the end of 2019. There was arrest
when they tried to hack one of the biggest banks in Eastern Central Europe, sorry, Africa.
And it was a great operation from the defender's perspective, but also it was
quite a big event for the attackers because they even joined with Rue Rue Shepherds then,
and some members of the Rue Rue Shepherds were also arrested during this police action.
How it looks in 2020. So many, nothing is stable. Those groups are mixing with each other. Rue Rue
grabs on, consultants are regrouping. And this is the East Africa threat landscape. However, on the
other hand, we have also groups from West Africa like Coruseta, and this is also a very interesting
story because there are some links that they operate with TA505, which is a very prolific
group. We could hear today Vitaly's presentation about the cooperation between this group and
Lazarus. Always those cooperations between different redactors is very interesting to research.
And this is the timeline, and this timeline and this history also affected the
development and the modus operandi of those groups, and we'll show it on the example of the key loggers.
Let's focus on some details about some of the groups, for example, Silent Cards.
It has lots of members, also it's African gang capabilities. Again, they use GoToPC,
AnyPC, C-DUBE, but the new version, new updated version, and the key logger, which is called
LandCruiser, but very similar to the old key loggers of the Fork Bombo. In this case, so in the
case of Silent Cards, they use insiders, but it doesn't have to be an ICT personnel, it could be
anyone with access, and sometimes it happened that even a janitor could enable an access to
those groups and connect the laptop somewhere to the network. They have very fast operational
They have very fast operational tempo. They use also a lot of cloud services, like
exfiltrating key logging to FTP, DriveHQ, to Gmail. They have quite wide targeting, for example,
not only financial institutions, but also insurance sector, also hospitals.
The group called The Consultants, so the next group created by the same guy who
united the Fork Bombo cartel. In their case, for example, apart from other tools, they also use
W-Agent, another commercial freely available software for remote access control,
and Python key logger called CocoLogger. They also connect the creditors, so whenever
they use W-Agent, they have to use the infrastructure from this service.
And GrubZone, general description, but later on, after our case studies, we'll see how the GrubZone
cluster looks in 2020. So in general, they use backdoors like Matterpreter, PS Empire,
Caesarrat, Rotnetter, so they experiment. You can see that they do not attach to one of the tools,
they experiment, they mix the tools, probably because they want to
have very low AV detection. They do not focus that much on some obfuscations on evading AV in
a technical way. Rather, they seek for new tools that are not that well known, that they do not
have the signatures, and we'll see it later on during the case studies. Apart from freely available
RATs, they use also commercial software for remote access control like AnyDesk,
Root, Symbot, and again, they use the keylogger. So this is quite common for different groups,
they use Hail Mary keylogger, and they also target the financial sector, a very successful group.
So let's go to the first case study about the Python keyloggers. So we'll also analyze the
initial, the origin of the keyloggers from the Fork Bombo cartel.
And this is one origin, there is a main function, probably copied and pasted to the
original keylogger of the Fork Bombo cartel. That's how you utilize,
how you use keylogging in Python. Even the variables were not changed, and you could
see that the same variables are present in different keyloggers of different groups.
Some parts are also not changed and are common among those keyloggers. For example,
the name of the file where the logs are stored, so all the keys that are pressed by the victim,
is usually named after the username, so after the victim username. And you can see also the
commented section in the green, where previously the Fork Bombo cartel used to exfiltrate
those logs to Gmail, and that's why the name of the cluster comes from, Fork Bombo.
Later on, they decided to leave the archive with the locked keys on the machine,
and exfiltrated using the command control channel.
And you could see on that picture, the comparison between the Cocoa Logger, which is a
tool from the consultants, and the Land Cruiser, which is a tool used by Silent Cards, that there
are many similarities, and the changes are very slight. Some parts are commented, some imports
are commented, because they don't use them anymore, or maybe they experiment with some
exfiltration to FTP. But generally, the way they lock the keystrokes, and the way they form the
log, they create the log, is the same among different versions of those African keyloggers.
And those are common artifacts that I gathered for those AFTs. Those files are usually quite large,
because the Python scripts are compiled to exe files with PyInstaller. The filenames are
masquerading known software, like OneNote, Adobe Exe, and they are usually located by adversaries
in program data. However, the logs are saved to program data, but they could be also located in
user profile, or all users profile. And this is also a good threat hunting hint, that often
adversaries put files, they use those locations as their staging folders,
and this is a good also threat hunting rule, that you could try to detect if there are any files
created there, because usually there should be a folder structure, and not single files
located in those directories. And the filenames are often based on the username,
and the extensions are different. It could be in different archives, or renamed extensions to some
system files, like any sys. And those keyloggers usually have run keys persistence. So very simple,
not sophisticated persistence in the registry, and that's why those keyloggers are run after every
reboot of the operating system. Is it possible to easily detect such keyloggers?
Usually not, because they are compiled by the PyInstaller, so there is a runtime environment
for the script. So you cannot try to create the error rule for specific characters that you could
find after the compilation of this to this Python script. However, there are quite unique imports
in the script, and for example, I used them to hunt for those keyloggers. It's very hard to
find the keylogger for a specific group, but with this Yara, for example, you could find
a group of keyloggers that are with high confidence associated with the African threat groups,
and later on, after the compilation, analysts could gather more information, and apply a second
Yara rules to the decompiled script, and then cluster the malware.
So you could see that the core, the origin of the keyloggers is unchanged, and usually there
are small differences, and also small differences how they use those keyloggers, how they choose the
directories. So this is quite common. Now we will focus on Grabson infrastructure,
and their capabilities from 2020.
Actually, we'll try to analyze one of the IPs, and this IP was found in one of the public resources
from online services. If this topic also finds you interesting, I really recommend
visiting their web page, and reading their materials, which is often a fascinating story.
So I found this IP, and I tried to analyze if there is any information that I could gather
more and reach about this IP. What are those new Python 3.0 capabilities of those groups?
That was my analytic question. So if we go to Shodan, and especially the beta version,
which offers the history in its GUI, and really recommends trying beta version of Shodan,
not the old one, because history of the previously indexed information is very useful during such
investigations. Is there anything interesting? For sure, ports like 3306, 3389 could be very
interesting, because those are ports connected with MySQL database, with RDP. So if we check
those unusual ports, we could learn more about infrastructure, about previous actions of this
threat group. Generally, this IP belongs to the hosting, which, as you can see on the screen,
very often offers some VPSs, VMs, focused on offensive security capabilities, like Kali Linux,
Parallel Security, Tor hidden service also, for example. So it is also very important to know that
such a group prefers this type of hosting, because whenever in later investigations,
we'll gather new data, this could help us to support our hypothesis, for example, if the next
IP belongs to that group, and if it is also the same hosting, that this could be an indicator for,
that could help us to support our hypothesis. So if we check the RDP on that
host that was served several weeks ago, we could find out that there is a message
related to the National Bank of Kenya. So probably what the adversary did was that
they tunneled out the access to the computer inside the National Bank of Kenya, and they accessed
that workstation after tunneling out this traffic. So this is one of the indicators that they
successfully breached this financial institution.
And if we would like to analyze what was on port 8080, which was associated with this new Python
free backdoor capabilities, we could find out that there is not much information, something about
something from August, something from July, and probably not related to this backdoor.
Because as far as I learned, this backdoor was used in the beginning of the year.
So what kind of backdoor they are probably using? If you take the strings that are also available
on this website, you could easily find the project on Google. There are only seven
hits in Google, and there is an IJR shell project on GitHub. This is not a human resources project,
but a backdoor with a server component written in Python, Python free actually.
And it could be used on many of the platforms like Linux, MacOS, Windows. It has the
capabilities also to validate the client, and you could also filter out the client. So maybe
there is not much information on this C2 that we analyze because there was a kind of a firewalling.
But if you take the same string, which is quite unique, and there were only seven hits in Google,
and you check it on VirusTotal, there is also not much, only two files with those strings.
But you could see also the detections, and have a look. There are only, after the compilation
of this Python scripts to exit file, there is only one AV detection using the static signature.
So probably that's the reason why the GrubZone group tries to utilize new
capabilities and tries to find something that evades AV detection.
So what about C2 server component? Can we learn something about it? Are there any traces on this IP
related to this project? So this is a Python-based HTTP server,
and I found only one indicator in January that this could be
the time when the project was deployed and was active, and you could see the header connected
with Python 3 and the project Werkzeug. So on the above pictures you have
parts from the source code, and below you have the HTTP response from the IP that we
analyzed and is attributed to GrubZone in this year. So I tried to play a little bit with this
project and try it out to find a way if there is any possibility to fingerprint this C2 server,
and maybe to find new instances, maybe to track if anybody on the internet is using that kind
of capabilities. So when I used curl for experiments, I received similar headers that I
saw on this IP that was belonging to GrubZone. Of course the version of Python was
different because I had different environment, but other headers were quite similar or almost the same.
So just to check generally how many Werkzeug servers are deployed in the internet, there are like
160,000 servers. If you look for this specific version, the number is quite lower
and quite manageable, it's about 300.
However, if we take those headers which are quite unique to this project, the numbers
are being filtered out, and later on I also tried to analyze the source code of the C2
component, and there is one resource registered, the commander. So whenever you send the GET
to the commander URL, you receive the 308 permanent redirect, not very popular HTTP response,
and this permanent redirect redirects to the commander with slash at the end, and then you
receive HTTP response 200. So this kind of a behavior that when you send the GET commander
without slash, you get 308 permanent redirect, and then you send the right GET to the commander
with slash, and you receive HTTP response 200. This kind of a behavior is something very unique
to this Python C2 server, and with this knowledge, it is very possible to search in census, to search
in showdown for those servers, because in this case, I'm trying to find out what servers are
giving me the response 302, because this is the response when I said the simple GET to the root,
and I only focus on 302, and if I want to be 100% sure, I can then send the GET to the commander
URL, and be absolutely sure that there is a HR shell server behind.
That was the example of a search for census. This is an example in the syntax that is used by showdown.
So generally, I'm looking for the specific headers, but I'm not looking for the response 200.
This response only happens when you send the correct URL, and in this case,
showdown census are sending just the most basic GETs to the root.
What are other C2 fingerprints on this IP server? Can we learn more about the adversary?
What kind of services they used this year when they were operating with this server hosted
there? So there is quite a unique subject for the SSL certificate, and when you take
this subject and try to search the database for SSL certificates,
for example, in census, there are only two IPs that are currently hosting SSL certificates with
such a subject. One is our well-known IP that begins with 145, but there is also another one,
and hosted in the same IP address range of the OVH hosting, which rents place to the
second hosting company that offers VPSs. However, this second IP, I'm not sure if it is
related to GrubZone, but it's always worth for thread intel analysts to mark such information,
and maybe later on, when our investigations gather more data, we collect more information,
we collect more information, maybe later on, we could connect this new IP with GrubZone cluster.
And in thread intel world, we also use very often markings with our confidence level,
so we could market with very low confidence level. This is the IP that possibly belongs
to GrubZone, and maybe later on, when we get more data, more confidence, we could change this
assessment. And there are also other interesting C2 fingerprints that I found related to this IP.
Actually, on another port, there was another HTTP response with such a body,
get file not specified in URL. And when I took this string again into Google, I found only one
response. There was a blog post about a man who showed how to create a file server in Golang
language and to host files. So it looks that the adversary took the code and hosted this Golang
server just to serve the files. They only did small modification. They added some HTTP response
headers. And my opinion is that they added those headers because they use this server to download
files on the victim machines using their browsers, so not using the C2 channel. And those headers
are there to make sure that the browser does not send any warnings that there is a problem with
extension and the MIME type. And that's why those extension problems, file type problems are
neglected. So if you take this specific string, you can only find currently one IP address
well known to us. But whenever they decide to use it again, this type of service somewhere else,
probably it would be quite easy to find them if they decide to continue these capabilities
on different infrastructure. Using Showdown, there is a very convenient way to use the
hashes of the responses. Showdown hashes the responses and you could use the hash.
And the result is also the same. So this service is served on two ports on this IP.
Some other hints about hunting their tools. For example, the client part
of the HR shell, after the compilation with the Pi installer to Windows executable,
there is a manifest file in the resources. And when you try to look, try to find for other
samples that have the same manifest file in the resources, you only find the HR shell
samples. For example, it is that manifest file, very unique to this project. And when you
search for these resources, for example, in the virus total database, in the latest indices,
you get only 15 files and all those files are compiled HR shell client component.
Is there anything else suspicious on this host? Yeah, there are some more interesting things
that were hosted on this IP. For example, in February, in March, April, there was such a
response, probably some of you that are familiar with offensive security frameworks, they know what
kind of tool that could be. So this is a default method pretty response.
In January on this on the same IP, there was a PS Empire hosted. This is a very also very typical
default response from the PS Empire c2. However, I do not associate this activity with this
cluster. Why is that? Because the the fingerprint of the SSH. So we had today the presentation about
fingerprinting, very interesting, and fingerprinting is very useful in our daily job.
So in this case, we we know that the fingerprint of the SSH service was changed on the 24th of
January. So and it was presence till now. And everything before 24 could be a different build
of the operating system, it could be same actor that reinstalled the software. But we can't have
even moderate confidence for that. So up to now, I do not include those information that
this is belong, this could be related to the African threads. It could be totally somebody
else, even the red team. In December, there was also something interesting. This is a typical
response from the cobalt strike is the same actor, we don't have hard evidence for clustering that
could be somebody else that that uses that one cloud hosting.
So generally, what we learned about grabzone summary, so the capabilities they use, they use HR shell
from other samples from other knowledge, we know that they use RG, RG rat free, they use still
metal pretor, they use RDP tunneling with probably ng rock. So when they breach the
victim organization, they try to tunnel out
some protocols to have easier access to their infrastructure, they use tools downloaded via
victim browsers, because they use the file server written in go. They, we see that they prefer such
infrastructure created in the hosting company named cloud one host.
They don't use domain based infrastructure, they use only IP based infrastructure,
and about something about the victim. So through the analysis of their infrastructure, we learned
that they were probably successful against breaching National Bank of Kenya, which was also
supported by later evidence and different other sources that yes, that the crabs and was successful
in in breaching them. If you also feel interested in in those subjects, I really recommend going to
on it services to this. So to the blog of the company that really fights those threats, and
they don't only support them with instant response. And you could see that Africa threat
landscape is quite unique. And you could meet many of the techniques that are not very popular
somewhere somewhere else, like this hardware additions. Now, on the other hand, and defenders
are also working the other way around, because people from on it services are often have often
the authorization from government to hack back and they also hack back the city infrastructure
of the adversaries and lots of the samples are gathered from the from such
offensive network operations. And I have to admit that they are very brave people because they are
fighting them locally. And the threats are and the risk is quite real. It's not like a simple
analysis of threats when you're sitting miles away. They conduct very close proximity operations
against those threats. And those those gangs have big support from the politicians from
corrupted policemen. So yeah, so very interesting and great shop about to those people who fight
AFT groups. And thank you all for for watching, for listening. Hope you're also interested in this
new threat landscape new for me maybe also for for you too. Thank you
